not as compelling as her first book . I be a clinical psychologist , and I really enjoy author Gretchen Rubin 's first book the happiness project . I appreciate the organization address a different area each month as well as the foundation in research on happiness and well - being . I be hope that Rubin 's next book , well than before , would be a sort of followup . in some way , it be , this time with Rubin more specifically address how to manage habit in order to be more happy and satisfied . unfortunately , I do not like this book nearly as much in fact , I find it be a slog to get through the whole thing . my major problem with this book be something Rubin address in her"A note to the Reader"at the start of the book . she says"I see habit through the lens of my own experience , so this account be color by my particular personality and interest . " and that be just it -- i. e. , Rubin's"study"of habit be almost wholly base on what have work for she and for people she know . her prior book utilize over - frequent quote from her blog this one rely on anecdotal story from her family and friend . Rubin attempt to make her theory adaptable to all by come up with a theory of what she calls"the four tendencies,"or basically , four different approach to habit . she call these the Upholder , Questioner , Obliger , and Rebel . I do not find this model , which Rubin refer to throughout the book , to be at all helpful . whereas Rubin may find herself solidly in the"Upholder"category , I personally be divide between Upholder and Questioner , and I do not really respond to the suggestion for either . use this basic framework , Rubin go on to create many , many more almost arbitrary category . be you a Lark or an Owl again , I ' m in - between . a Mararthoner , Sprinter , or Procrastinator ? Underbuyer or Overbuyer ? Simplicity Lover or Abundance Lover ? Finisher or Opener ? Familiarity Lover or Novelty Lover ? promotion - Focused or Prevention Focused ? small Steps or big step ? and all of that be only in the second chapter ! it feel very bogged down , confusing , and often irrelevant , at least for I . Rubin go on to address the importance of monitoring habit and to discuss the foundation for create habit . there be some solid , general tip in this section . but eventually , she fall back into create force category , such as the series of"loopholes,"or exception to habit . again , there be some good idea here and there , but they tend to get lose among the clutter . one of Rubin 's chapter be called"Data point of one . " this be probably the good way to view this book -- that is , as one person 's experience , with suggestion that may or may not relate personally . give both that I do not see an overall general application to Rubin 's theory and that I really do not enjoy this book overall , I would not recommend it .
